transcript.content: The Ricky Gervais show on Guardian Unlimited.
Welcome to the 6th podcast in a series of twelve. The Ricky Gervais show available online with me, Ricky Gervais, Steve Merchant.
Hello.

And Karl Pilkington halfway through after this, then Karl, you enjoying it? It's got a great response. We're the number one podcast in the world. We've had thousands of emails and messages and it's just great to know that people all around the world are listening. Don't you think? It's great? Isn't it?

I should just point out, Rick, that we've had a few emails, including one from Mark Pavlidis, that says that some of the people listening on the enhanced podcast. So you know these fancy people, super rich people who can afford that one. Apparently sometimes if they try to pause the show halfway through, it sort of freezes and they've got a problem restarting it. And he's saying that apparently you should just hold down menu and select and that'll reboot, reboot it. So I don't know if you have had that problem.
Hold on, who's pausing this show halfway through?
I don't understand it.
I can't believe it. This is like a book that you can't put down.
What have they got that is better?

You know what can be better than listening to Carl's drivel and his stupid theories? Unbelievable. We've got a little email straight away, Carl, from Nikki in Beverly Hills, California. She says, carl, you rock. I hate it when Ricky and Steve ridicule you. I checked out your picture on rickyjavez.com, although your head is not normal, that's no reason to ridicule you. You look gimp, but I never judge a book by the COVID Cheers.
Is that what you've got to say?
Well, it's only because I've got no air though, isn't it? That's why it gives that effect.

No, it's perfectly round your head, perfectly spherical head. Your face is slightly too big for it. It always goes over the, almost goes over the sides. Perfectly round head, pug little nose, funny gimp eyes with no expression. Hang dog. Look like a little mouth, like a little lamprey. Not formed, not human formed. The way your expression is like you've had a lobotomy. Your head goes weird at the back. It's got a little nod in it. It's really strange, your face. And you're stupid.

We've had a lot of emails saying that. Paraphrasing, but talking of emails, you know, a couple of I can't remember which show it was. But you mentioned, Carl, that you'd only recently seen a chinese homeless person, and it really surprised you because you'd never seen a chinese homeless person.
And I actually went along with that. I've still never seen a chinese homeless person.

Well, that's. Other than obviously, people contributing monkey news, the search for chinese homeless people has been overwhelming on the email. People are just. I mean, people are actually going out looking for chinese homeless people. Now, I can just tell you now that there's a few responses from Los Angeles, people saying there are quite a lot of chinese homeless people over there because apparently there's a huge homeless community in Los Angeles. So definitely, if you want to see them, Carl, that's the place to go. But we've had one from Vancouver, Canada, from a girl called Amy. And Amy herself is chinese. And she realized herself that she'd never really seen a chinese homeless person. And although she says that apparently Vancouver has the first or second largest chinese population in Canada, she'd never seen them. And she actually went for a walk around the Chinatown in her area looking for them, and she could not find any on that particular day. So again, Canada, obviously not a place to go for a chinese home.
It was just a point, though. I don't want people sort of-

Well, hold on, though. Wait, I'll stop you there. "Hello, Ricky, Steve and Karl. I live in New York City and have seen a Chinese homeless person. Not only is he Chinese, but he is also a midget. He's been living on the streets for the last 30 years. He used to dress in rags, but thanks to a coat drive, he's now wearing a fancy Adidas jacket." Right? Now he encloses a picture. He says he gave him 10 bucks to take the picture, and I've seen it, and he's a little Chinese midget fella
I'm just getting a bit worried that people are going out there, sort of looking for these. Because, you know-
Well, that's what you requested.
No, no, no. But all I was saying is I saw one. I didn't start saying, "Excuse me, can you just give us a smile? I'm taking your picture."
We've had loads of pictures of people.

I know, and it worries me a little bit. And I mean, it's not too bad about the one who took one of a little midget one because, you know, if he kicked off, it'd be quite easy to sort of hold him back. But I'm talking about fully grown-
So is that your warning to people? Don't be taking pictures of fully grown Chinese homeless?
Well, yeah, I'm just saying, you know, don't, don't be messing about going up to strangers and that and annoying them and stuff. Right? Maybe-
Well, I think that's a good rule of thumb: don't annoy them. But, I mean, but that is a hell of a sighting, isn't it? We asked for a Chinese homeless, and they gave us a Chinese midget homeless.
Many of the listeners are aware, Karl, that you're sort of fascinated by smaller people.
Well, he's fascinated by difference, I think.
Yes.

I don't think he's having a go at people. You're not having, when you, when you sort of stare at someone because they don't look like you and let's face it, most people don't look like you. You're not having a go, are you?

Well, it's like I say, first time I saw Steve, I was never, never having a go, it was just, "Oh, that's different." But, you know, like, you know Steve, I was never having a go. It's just that thing of, "Oh, right. Interesting."
What do you mean?
No, just, just, you know, we've said before about when I saw Steve, and what have you. And now I've got used to it and Steve-
Got used to it? What do-
Well, you know, my feeling with this, I don't really know where he's coming from.
But Steve knows I'm not having a go either.
Yeah.
Karl used to carry around a book that was called The Top 50 Freaks of All Time.

Well, it's interesting you should mention that because we actually had an email from Richie, who says that he's been a fan of ours for many years, and he's listened to lots of the radio shows we've done in the past and things. And he says, of all the people you've discussed, Karl, in the past, including some of the people from your, your odd magazines, who would you most like to spend the day with? Of all those people that you've encountered.
Favourite, favourite of all?
Well, certainly who you would want to spend time with, who you feel would be the most fascinating, the most interesting. You know, I mean, let's just recap on some-
There was Pillow Man, the bloke with no arms, no legs that can roll a cigarette with his mouth.
Yeah.
No? Not impressed with him?
That's not sufficient.
What about the three legged juggler?
So hang on. Let's just recap for new listeners. This was a man with three legs?
Three legs, right. And it said his job, he became a juggler.
Okay.
Not using the, you know, the gift that he'd been given.
What would you suggest?
Anything. Running, swimmer. Just, you know.
Yeah.
But yeah, what are the others, what are the other ones?
There's a picture of a gentleman. You was fascinated by him. He used to play the piano.
Oh, he's got a tiny head, isn't he?
Yeah, that's that, that's the one who, he sort of ages fast, right? So like every other week he's having a birthday and stuff. And yeah, that was weird.

He's not having a birthday every other week. His body's just aged, so it has the appearance, the, his biology is sort of like, like he's 70, but he's only like 15. He doesn't, they don't have a birthday every week, you idiot.
But yeah, I don't know about knocking about with one for a long time, though.
Only for a day.
Yeah. Suppose it depends what I'm up to because if, you know, if we're going out and about, the pillow man would just be a bit of a drag whereas-
Whereas if, you know, if you're going for a walk across, you know, the three legged guy. Ideal.
Oh brilliant, oh.
The Ricky Gervais Show on Guardian Unlimited.

Lots and lots of people emailing just with questions for Karl. People just want to get his opinion on stuff. So if you have questions for Karl, keep them coming in. Podcast@rickygervais.com. We can't really reply to your emails, but we do read them, so we really appreciate them coming in. Just a couple of quick ones for you, Karl. Wendy says if Karl had to eat the same dinner every day for the rest of his life, what would, what would he eat? She's, she mentioned this because she was having Christmas dinner and it was a big, you know, she loves Christmas dinner.
The trouble with Christmas dinner, I mean, the roast dinner is the king of dinners and the Christmas dinner is the king of roast dinners.
Yes.
But you can't have one every day.
No, it's absurd.
It's brilliant.
We have three meats in our house.
It's unbelievable. The amount of meats is just amazing. It's just a plate of meat.
It's just meat, yeah.
With one Brussels sprout, one token Brussels sprout and the gravy.
Um, you see, it depends. Don't it? I mainly eat just so I keep going. I'm not that bothered about, because I don't really taste it anyway. I just shove it down.
You're like, oh, you're like a horse.

But at what point did it become important that things were sort of, you know, seasoned or garnish to go with it and stuff at the end of the day, we're all eating, aren't we? So you can move about and that you've got energy.
We need to know what we're tasting, don't we? Because we need to have certain things. We need sugar, we need salt, so we need to know what they taste like, to know we're getting them.
No but now we've got chefs, so leave that up to them to make sure we're getting the salt-
But I thought you were talking about an evolutionary standpoint and how it evolved. Not there was a little chef in the-
Do you think that's likely?

No, leave it for them to make sure, you know, we're getting safe food. I mean, to be honest, it annoys me the way people worry about food now and how, how there's so much to choose from. I think it's got out of hand. I'll watch-
Any form of choice really worries you, doesn't it?
No.
You don't like choice.
No, choice is good, but not too much. It's like with anything. Now, if you go into a toffee shop, these, like, loads of-
Sorry-
Where are you going to find a toffee shop?
You're in- you're in a fairy tale.
Yeah, yeah, yeah. You're in a Dickens tale, in- in the 19th century.
You're in Shrek, and you-
Yeah and you go into a toffee shop-
What's your point? You go into a toffee shop.
Ricky and Steve laugh
What I'm saying- you know when you go into a shop full of toffees?
Ricky laughs
You just come from the candlestick maker.
Ricky laughs
You go- You go in there and there's just too much choice. It's like, what? And I can stand there up to, like four minutes. Sort of going-
Up to four minutes.
Steve laughs
Ricky laughs
So specific!
Up to four minutes.
So he's in a toffee shop in a top hat-
Well he's only got four minutes- he's only got four minutes because you got to get down to the pea green boat that he's taking off in.
Ricky laughs
Yeah. Good morrow!
Look, forget the toffee.
Could I have some of your finest Oxfordshire toffees?
So you'd prefer it was just one selection of toffee? That's all they've got.
Or maybe two.
Steve laughs

What I'm saying is, right, there's now too much choice. Whenever you get a menu in a restaurant, it's not like- you don't just go: "Oh, right, what is the? Yeah, I'll have that." There's too much. It's like a book now, isn't it? You look at it all-
Steve laughs
And then you've got to that point where that people are even taking a risk when they're eating.
What do you mean?
Erm. You know, in Japan or China or something, they're eating that fish-
Ricky laughs
-that if it's not cooked right, it can kill you. Alright? Not worth the risk when there's so many other fish.
Yeah, I agree.
Have mackerel. Have a bit of cod or whatever.
Ricky laughs
Why take the risk? Yeah.
Soon as there's a risk, take it off. Off the menu.
Ricky laughs
I agree. I totally agree.
Not worth it.
We- We've got a fish that might or might not kill you. Well, um, is there anything that definitely won't kill you? Yeah, bit of chicken won't kill you.
I'll play safe then. I'll have that.
I'll have that. I'll have the chicken.
That's what I'm saying.
The Ricky Gervais show on Guardian Unlimited.
But anyway, we were talking about sayings and that. Erm a stitch in time saves nine. Don't, don't, you know, I'm never gonna use that, I don't think.
Ricky laughs
You're never gonna understand it fully, are you?
Suzanne repairs me stuff anyway.
Ricky laughs
So it doesn't really matter. But what about the one- about the one in greenhouses and that?
People who live in glass houses, shouldn't throw stones?
Yeah.
Does that confuse you? You never understood that one?
No, that's, that's a lot clearer, isn't it? It's sort of saying don't be chucking stuff about if you're surrounded by glass and what have you.
Yeah, but don't forget it's an analogy, it's a metaphor. It's not to be taken literally. It's not really just talking to people who live in glass houses. It's saying- err-
Hang on. Sorry, before you say that, Rick, I just, I'm intrigued to know if he's fully got to grips with this. Just give us your explanation again of what you'd take that to mean.
Well just don't be chucking stuff about.
Ricky and Steve laugh
So-
Well if that was it, they'd just say that.
No, no, but, but that saying's been around a lot longer than we think. That's when people probably did live in basic glass houses and stuff.
No, no. Woah, woah, woah, woah, woahhh.
Who has ever lived in a glass house?
So this, they went- cavemen went from rock to a nice crystal structure, did they? What are you talking about? When did people live in glass houses?
What they mean now. When- when that saying's used now they mean sort of, you know, plasma tellies, ornaments.
No, they don't.
They're saying don't chuck stuff about 'cos you'll break it.
No, it's not about damaging your own property.
They don't mean you're inside the glass house throwing rocks inside your own glass house.

It's a metaphor. It means don't be having a go at people if you yourself have got more to lose. Do you know what I mean? It- it means it- it could be, it could be anything. Don't- don't start a war where you could come off bad as well. It's about how fragile your situation is. If you live in a glass house metaphorically, don't throw stones at someone else 'cos when he throws it back at you, your house is more easily damaged than his. Again, metaphorically.

It doesn't mean that if you're living in a glass house or in a house with other precious objects, you don't, in your own home, throw bricks about, because that would be a very specific audience that was trying to reach, that phrase. I mean, let's be honest, what kind of a mental case.
Do you know what, I think we've got to the crux of this. Alright? I- I think I can an- right, right. Karl, what is an analogy?
It's sort of like a little story told quickly.
Ricky laughs
Innit? It is though.
It's a little story told quickly. To what end?
Well, it depends what the story is.
Okay, give me a- give me an analogy.
Well, for me, I thought of one with the greenhouse, right?
It's- now it's a greenhouse. Before it was just a glass house.
I know, yeah. Yeah.
All right then, a glass house.
Okay.
Right. You do- what I mean is that glass house is metaphorical. It's about the fragility of your situation as compared to your aggression or your...
You see, I- I just prefer, sort of, you know, what you say is what you mean. So people in- who live in a glass house have to answer the door.
I don't know what that means.
Steve laughs
I don't know what that means. I mean-
Because-
You- you may be a genius, 'cos I don't get that. People who live in glass houses have to answer the door.
Okay, let him- let's hear his explanation.
Because the people knocking at the door will be able to see you because it's a glass house.
But what... ey?
But you literally mean it, don't you? There's no analogy there or metaphor for you. You literally mean if you live in a glass house and someone knocks the door-
You've got to answer the door.
So there's no- there's no hidden meaning there, is there?
Well, normally-
But couldn't that also- you'd have to add a number of other things, another- other caveats. Surely, if you live in a glass house, don't walk around naked.
Yeah.
If you live in a-
Steve laughs

The- these are literal. See, if you- now, you could- you could actually make that into quite a nice, uh, erm, saying there. Because if- if that meant- if someone said that to me and they weren't a shaved chimp, right? If they said 'people live in glass houses, have to answer the door', I'd think that means: 'Oh, yeah, it means that, um, there are no secrets. You can't hide behind anything. If you're- if you're very open, if you've chosen to be totally open all the time, you can't go back on it'. So people, if- if you wear everything on your sleeve, if you shout around and you tell the truth, you can't go back on it. They can see... they can see through you.
Yeah, it can mean that as well. Yeah.
Oh, that's handy. But just the idea that in your head that there should be sayings for people who live in glass houses. Who is it that's living in a glass house?
No, well I'm not talking about them. It's just that if everyone else is bringing up about these people who are living in glass houses, let's, let's get to the real problems we've got.
He still hasn't got to grips with the idea of the metaphor or the simile.
People who live in glass houses should live near a glazier.
Well, here's another saying, right, that I learned recently from a mate, right? Oh, there's an elephant in the room.
Okay, I haven't heard that one, but explain it to me.

It's like when you, when something's going on in a room, right? But no one's mentioning it because everyone's a bit too sort of- But in a way, it's better that it's out. It's like how, you know, you, whenever we go out for something to eat or a drink or something, it's normally after about five minutes, the sort of topic gets onto the shape of my head.
Yeah. Yeah. Well, I can't resist the shape of your head.
Right. So you're, you're happy talking.

It's the shape, though, is it? It's the state of it. No, outside and in. I mean, it's a fascinating little objet d'art, his head. It's perfectly round. It's got no hair where it should have, and it's hollow.
The features are slightly too small for the face.
Yeah. Unbelievable.

No, but what I'm saying is it's interesting how, like, I'm the elephant in the room, right? Nobody's talking about it. You mention it once, suddenly it's the talk of the town, is what I mean. Everybody starts joining in, going, well, yeah, it's round, but it does suit you. And these are people who I don't even know sometimes, and they're all dipping in. And that is an elephant in a room.
So you, you don't want people to discuss the shape of your head or the, or the lack of hair. You would feel better. You'd feel happier that they didn't mention that?
Sometimes I think it's better that it's out there. It's made me a stronger person, though. It's the same way you know, we were talking about religion and that. Samson and Delilah.
Yeah.

He got weaker without hair, whereas with me, I think it's, it's made me stronger because, you know, it's almost like it's treated like a disability. Everybody's sort of mentioning it and talking about it. What's it like having a bald head? And... You know what I mean? So it's made me stronger.
But would you ever wear a wig?
Not really.
What was a long wig like, Samson?

Well, the only time I wanted a wig was when I did jury duty once. And it was annoying that I was sat on the jury right in front of, like, these criminals. Right. Everybody else has got disguises. The judges have them wigs on. Right?
That's not disguise!
That's the disguise. That's why judges wear them, right?
No! Well, then why did they print their name in the paper and have a picture? What do you mean? It's a disguise?
It's a disguise.
No, if it was disguised, they'd go in with one of those glasses with a nose and the beard attached. If it was a disguise, all judges would look like Groucho Marx if it was a disguise.

Well, I'm just saying that's. That's what annoyed me when I was sat there on the front row, right. I couldn't have been any closer to the criminals, right? I was sat there and I thought, why didn't I just pop a little wig on or a pair of glasses?
I would have loved to have seen you in the front row at Crown Court.
No-

I would have loved to see it because in this country you're not allowed to show pictures of jurors. You can't take photos in a courtroom. So there's always these sketch artists that draw drawings and it's on the news. The idea that we'd have seen eleven people and a sort of Krusty the clown figure would have been amazing.
Yeah. I would love to see the artist doing you because it would be like "Complicated people, oh yeah, he looks inter, characterful" and then just a little round head.
Charlie Brown.
Yeah. Charlie Brown sitting on the end!
Karl, you said that your new year's resolution was that you were going to learn something every day. Have you learnt anything today?
If I can. Today, like, I don't know the full facts of it but-
Could I just say that when someone says they learn something new every day, that doesn't count if they forget it the next day? No, because that would be Groundhog Day learning.
Well, the thing I learnt today was about an octopus.
Oh yeah.
Go on.
What they can do is, you know, they've got eight legs and that.
Yeah.
They can, they can use, they can use six of them legs to cover their head so they look like a little stone. Use the other two to run off. Right?
He's thinking of Squiddly Diddly!
Yeah. It's a Disney image in his head.
But anyway, that's, that's, you know.
So he's pink, singing a song in your mind and running off, yeah.
No, but anyway. But something else I learned, right? It's mainly about animals and that. Because that's normally quite interesting.
Yeah.
There's a chicken somewhere.
Oh, yeah.
Oh, yeah. Specific.
And the owner of it was getting fed up because, you know, he had to feed it and that.
Embellishment. Embellishment, guesswork.
No, go on, let's hear it.
It wasn't giving anything back.
No eggs?

No eggs. Right? So he was like, "I'm sick of this." Anyway, someone told him, pop a little axe next to its little house, right? So when it comes out in the morning thinking, "I'll have another lazy day doing nothing," right? He saw this axe and suddenly it was like, "oh, aye, right."
Up for the chop, it thought.
Next day, it laid about six eggs.

It's rubbish, it's rubbish. A chicken wouldn't recognise an axe as a threat. It wouldn't, it wouldn't be able to reason that, oh, I better start working or I'll be, I'll be meat. I better start. It's absolute rubbish. Once again, it's this ridiculous thing. You got that one: personifying animals to reasoning powers better than yours. I mean, I think, you know, you make chickens and monkeys cleverer than you in your stories, which is weird. Okay, it didn't happen and wouldn't work. Next. What else haven't you learnt today?
No. Well, as always, things like that always get me thinking.
What else haven't you learned today?
No, hang on, his mind's working now. This apparently's got his mind working.
So that's rubbish.
Well, do you think then that it's worth looking after animals then, if there isn't any memory? If they don't know what's happening anyway, you're always going on about, don't be cruel to things.

Yeah, why would you be cruel? There's one thing about imagining chickens can reason and because they can't, being cruel to them. Why does it matter whether an animal can reason or not for you not to be cruel to it? The reason I don't like bloodsports isn't the fact that there's a fox missing. It's the, the psychology of people that get off on seeing an animal ripped to pieces. They wouldn't like it if it was a robot. They wouldn't care. For some reason in their psychology, they like, they like this sport. Why does it have to be a sport? They're not culling, they're not putting things down for a good. They like to see this fox ripped apart or a bull tortured for their own pleasure. That's why you shouldn't do it. Why would you ever want to be cruel to an animal, whether it can reason or not?

No, no, I mean, I don't mean really cruel, but I mean, like. Like, there's an advert on that that's on in the, you know, in Britain, advertising some supermarket, right? And it's saying, you know, we look at- Before, you know, we kill our chickens, what have you. They have a great life. This is like the voiceover, you see a happy chicken.
Yeah.
And it's going, errr- we give it a good little house to live in. It's got straw.
Yeah.
It eats good.
Yeah.
And then we kill it.
Yes. Well, that's better, isn't it?
Well, no, I don't think it is, though, is it? Because at the end of the day, if I was that chicken, right, I'm that chicken, loving me life. I can't believe me luck. Right?
Well, we'd be pleased because at least he'd be able to do the show and we'd have some interesting conversations.
Yeah.
So there it is, right? Wandering about. It's got its nice little field that it's working on.
Yeah.
It's got its nice food and everything. But it's gonna die.
Yeah, we're all gonna die.
But then if you were like a rubbish chicken that,
Steve laughs
That had like a rubbish life, you'd be going, oh, kill me.
Steve laughs
Karl, they're not thinking: "what's gonna happen tomorrow?"
They don't know that. They're gonna get. They're gonna get for the chop, are they?
A chicken's not going, I am fed up with this. I can't wait for that axe to be used on my neck.
Yeah, well, that's another- Now you've mentioned the cutting off of an head, right?
Yeah.
Of the chicken. That's something else I've learned. Right.
It's like a pinball, is mind.
Amazing, isn't it?
Ding dong, bong, dang, ding. dang. Oh, Eh. Ding, ding. Duh. Duh. Chicken. Eh. Uh. Head off. Doing.
No. Right. But erm this was in a proper science magazine as well.
Yeah.
So you can't have a go. This wasn't something on the Internet. This was printed in a magazine.
So? You read it.
Okay, and what was it?
And here. And here comes the filter. It's gonna come out nonsense.
Right, well-
You could have Professor Stephen Hawking sitting there whispering stuff in your ear and it could all be true. But when you said it: gobbledygook.
Let's see then. Let's see. Right? This. What they've done. They've done another experiment, right?
Yeah.

They've cut somebody's head off, right? And you know, they used to do it in the olden days where they put your head in a stock, cut it off for whatever reason, right? You've done something wrong, right? And the question that everybody used to talk about in the village was, you know, oh, I made eye contact with it, right? And it was a bit worrying because he was looking at me and he looked fed up and that.
No it's dead.
So they've put a bit of work into this and they've, they've done it again somewhere, right? And they've worked out that once when the head comes off the body, it stays alive and that.
No.
For 30 seconds.
Well, no, they don't know that. They can never know that.
No, they did it. They did this experiment.
What's alive? What's alive?
The head.
But there's loads of issues here. One, no one's experimenting with human beings cutting their head off, Karl.
You read this in, what, executioners monthly?
This is.
Two, Karl, it's what your definition of alive is, because you can be alive and have no conscience.
No, no, but this is, this is where it gets weird, right?
Yeah, this is where it gets weird, you talking about it.
So the head's off, right? And what they did was they chucked a load of questions at it.
Ricky laughs
All sanctioned by the government.
Yeah.

So they had the head lands perfectly on the neck and goes, what do you want to know? So they're asking questions and it's going, do you know what? To be quite honest, I'll answer your question. They'll be annoyed about the execution still.
Well, that, that was the interesting thing they said it's about.
No, it's not. It didn't happen.
Let me hear.
Oh, don't talk.
Let me hear it.
What are you talking about? Who? These people around in white coats going, quick, ask it a question. It's bleeding.

Right. So they said for about 25 to 30 seconds, the last 5 seconds it is sort of like, can't be bothered answering them, right? But after that, apart from that, they were chucking stuff. I don't think it spoke. I don't think it was like, yeah, two and two, four and stuff. It was more. It was to do with blinking.
So blink once if you say yes.

So I told you, said, listen, when you die, you're probably not going to be able to talk because your jaw is going to be on the ground. You're not going to be able to open your mouth.
